questions.question: Which logical operator is represented by the symbol '∧'?
questions.explanation: The symbol '∧' represents conjunction (AND). The conjunction p ∧ q is true only when both p and q are true.

questions.question: What is the precedence order of logical operators from highest to lowest?
questions.explanation: The precedence order of logical operators is: NOT (highest), AND, OR, IMPLIES (lowest). Parentheses can override this precedence.

questions.question: What does the NAND operator produce?
questions.answer: The negation of AND (false only when both inputs are true)
questions.explanation: NAND (NOT AND) produces the negation of the AND operation. It is false only when both inputs are true, and true in all other cases.

questions.question: Which operator is commutative?
questions.explanation: Both AND and OR operators are commutative, meaning p ∧ q = q ∧ p and p ∨ q = q ∨ p. Implication is not commutative.

questions.question: What is the symbol for the biconditional operator?
questions.explanation: The biconditional operator is represented by ↔ or ≡. It means 'if and only if' (iff) and is true when both propositions have the same truth value.

questions.question: How many inputs does a unary operator take?
questions.explanation: A unary operator takes only one input. Negation (NOT) is an example of a unary operator, while AND, OR, and implication are binary operators.

questions.question: What does the NOR operator produce?
questions.answer: The negation of OR (true only when both inputs are false)
questions.explanation: NOR (NOT OR) produces the negation of the OR operation. It is true only when both inputs are false, and false in all other cases.

questions.question: Which operator is represented by the symbol '→'?
questions.explanation: The symbol '→' represents implication (conditional). The statement p → q means 'if p then q' and is false only when p is true and q is false.

questions.question: What property states that (p ∧ q) ∧ r = p ∧ (q ∧ r)?
questions.explanation: Associativity allows regrouping of operations without changing the result. Both AND and OR operators are associative.

questions.question: Which logical operator is also called the exclusive disjunction?
questions.explanation: XOR (exclusive OR) is called the exclusive disjunction. It is true when exactly one of the two inputs is true, but not both.
